awd_titl_txt: REU: Synthesis, Assembly and Characterization of Soft Matter Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:
The objective of the REU site at Cleveland State University (CSU) is to involve sophomore and junior physics and engineering majors in meaningful interdisciplinary research projects within soft matter science/engineering. This will encourage students to pursue graduate studies in physics and engineering. Fundamental to CSU's REU site is intentional faculty mentoring, particularly, for underrepresented and minority students in physics and engineering. Soft matter is a group of materials that includes liquids, colloids, polymers, gels, and biological materials. Soft matter researchers combine physics, chemistry, biology, and engineering to study the unique properties and applications of these materials. Each participating student will work for 10 weeks directly with a faculty advisor in the nurturing and collaborative atmosphere of CSU's Department of Physics and Department of Chemical & Biomedical Engineering. CSU's focus on "engaged learning" has cultivated a strong culture of support for undergraduate research. REU students will benefit from this culture through one-on-one mentoring from experienced faculty and a variety of professional development opportunities. Students' scientific and professional development will be supported through: a) a weekly science seminar introducing students to the multifaceted nature of soft matter research and careers in research; b) a weekly student seminar with informal student updates and formal student presentations; c) a final poster presentation at the Northeast Ohio NSF-REU Undergraduate Research Conference; d) travel support for presentation at a regional/national conference after REU; e) development of a long-term relationship with a scientific mentor; and f) a multitude of REU social activities to help develop networks among REU students as well as with student researchers from CSU and other REUs in Northeast Ohio. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:
The scientific focus of this REU is soft matter, a subfield of condensed matter that encompasses a large variety of materials, from liquids that can be used for transport and for directing assembly of other soft or hard materials, to polymers that can be used for electronic or mechanical applications, to biological materials which people study to better mimic nature's complexity and develop new pathways towards healing. Undergraduate researchers will work directly with faculty members from two departments to contribute significantly to meaningful scientific research projects. Several of the available research projects are collaborations among the nine faculty committed to the REU site.  REU participants will conduct original research via specially designed student projects within three main foci: 1) Microgel and Hydrogel Nanoparticles: Designing environmentally sensitive nanoparticles for a variety of applications and fundamental studies of volume phase transitions; 2) Anisotropic Soft Matter Thin Films: Driving self-assembly of soft matter to develop thin films with unique properties tied to the shape anisotropy of the materials; and 3) Soft Matter Fluid Flow: Striving to better understand and to improve mixing in liquid soft matter systems and use liquid flow to test and understand biological phenomena. Students engaged in an authentic research experience at CSU's REU will contribute significantly to cutting edge soft matter research with potential applications ranging from drug delivery to organic solar cells. Student research experience will be supplemented with a series of scientific and professional development seminars, research presentation opportunities, and development of a scientific network via social activities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the REU site at Cleveland State University (CSU) was to guide three cohorts of motivated undergraduates through the scientific method via an independent, scientifically significant research project. In doing so we (a) taught students the basics of research; (b) developed their technical communication and research dissemination skills; (c) encouraged them to consider graduate school; and (d) immersed them in a highly collaborative network of nurturing mentors committed to guiding them through their careers.

The REU included 12 projects advised or co-advised by 9 faculty in the physics and chemical/biomedical engineering departments at CSU. 26 REU students from 18 colleges in 10 states alongside 5 CSU-sponsored students advanced the projects in soft-matter physics with three research foci:

  1. Polymers, proteins, and gels: Can an understanding of protein and polymer fundamental properties and phase transitions help us harness the power of environmentally sensitive nanoparticles and gels?
  2. Self-Assembly and Anisotropic Soft Matter: Can we drive self-assembly of anisotropic soft matter to exploit its properties for applications ranging from electronics to biomimetics?
  3. Soft Matter Fluid Flow: Can we better understand and improve mixing in liquid systems and use liquid flow to test and understand biological phenomena?

The REU had positive outcomes in terms of Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts.

Intellectual Merit:

The REU students have made significant contributions to scientific knowledge through 88 presentations (most by the students themselves) at 9 local, 9 regional, and 12 national conferences as well as through 9 peer-reviewed publications, 2 peer-reviewed abstracts,1 US utility patent application, and 5 manuscripts in preparation. This volume of work contributed to the body of knowledge in the three REU research foci:

            A. Polymers, proteins, and gels:

  • Studies of swelling/deswelling mechanism and dynamics of environmentally sensitive polymeric microgels: Freeman et al., Macromolecules 53, 11, 9244 (2020); Tietjen et al., The Ohio Journal of Science 118, A49 (2018); Scherer et al., in preparation.
  • Developing wet scanning electron microscopy technique to visualize the dynamics of microgels in solution: Tietjen et al., JURP, 30, 1, 31 (2021); Dobrila et al., The Ohio Journal of Science 118, A48 (2018).
  • A study of phase transitions in absinthe to understand the formation of the milky louche upon cold water addition: Bickel et al., ACS Omega, 6, 17674 (2021).
  • A study to design, express, and characterize protein-based hydrogel nanoparticles that can trap and release drugs: Maraschky et al., in preparation.

            B. Self-Assembly and Anisotropic Soft Matter:

  • A study of purification, structural control, and self-assembly of Boron Nitride nanotubes which may be used for thermal interface materials and optoelectronics: Kode et al., ACS App. Nano Materials 2, 2099 (2019); Ao,G., Aligned Boron Nitride Nanotube Films, US utility patent application #16/775,319 (2020).
  • A study of organic molecule crystallization via surface reconstructions and simulations that can be used for electronics: Martin et al. in preparation.
  • Microscopy/scattering studies of Janus/anisotropic particles: Rashidi et al. in preparation.

            C: Soft Matter Fluid Flow

  • Studies of mixing in microfluidic channels and mixers of various geometries: Clark et al. COMSOL Conference 1 (2018); Micromachines 9, 107 (2018); J. Micromechanics and Microengineering 29, 075012 (2019).
  • A study of gold nanoparticle formation in microfluidic mixers: Sarsfield et al., Chemical Engineering Technology 44, 622 (2021).
  • Studies of the mechanical structure of primary cilia, which is important for understanding the kidney disease: Praljak et al., Mathematical Biosciences & Engineering 17, 1787 (2020); Resnick et al., in preparation.

Broader Impacts:

  • Benefiting science and technology via published/presented results and the patent.
  • Advancing STEM education by helping 26 REU and 5 CSU-sponsored students develop research, technical communication, and professional development skills.
    • REU engaged students in independent research - a new experience for many participants as 65% came from departments that do not offer PhD (e.g. with limited research opportunities). Student assessments showed significant growth in research-related skills after REU (e.g. 22% growth in student ability to identify next research steps and 50% in ability to present research).
  • Helping students to build a research network with peers, faculty mentors, and STEM researchers.
    • Student participation at local/regional/national conferences (pic 1), REU Science Colloquia, and trips to NASA and Liquid Crystal Institute (pics 2&3) expanded their networks.
  • Inspiring ~21% of students into graduate studies (percentage of students interested climbed from 56% before to 77% after the REU). Currently, 66% of REU alumni are in graduate programs (10 PhD/7 MS); another 12% plan to do it. Two REU alumni received NSF?s Graduate Research Fellowships.
  • Encouraging highly collaborative and interdisciplinary research environment by the nature of REU projects, student interdepartmental co-advising, and Colloquia speaker selection.
  • Supporting women by admitting 20% of the cohort (national physics average); promoting CUWiP conferences and women physicist speakers (pics 4&5).
  • Promoting STEM within the general public and training students in the importance of public scientific communication via outreach to high school students by REU participants (pic 6).

Last Modified: 05/31/2022
Modified by: Kiril Streletzky

Images (1 of )
  • Each summer Northeast Ohio Undergraduate Research Symposium (NOURS) gathers students & faculty from five Northeast Ohio federally supported undergrad research programs. Our students attended NOURS 2017-19. In 2019 CSU hosted NOURS with 70+ undergrads (59 posters,8 talks) and NASA speaker, Dr.W.Myers
    Andrew Resnick
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 1: NOURS 2019 symposium at CSU
  • Each year the REU cohort and CSU-supported students would go to NASA Glenn Research Center (GRC) for a tour of research facilities. In 2018 (pictured) we were hosted by Dr. J. Mackey and explored Martian Dust Lab, ZeroG Facility, Flow Boiling Lab, and Icing Research Tunnel.
    Kiril A Streletzky
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 2: REU trip to NASA GRC (2018)
  • Each year the REU cohort and CSU-supported students also went to Kent State University Liquid Crystal Institute, the birthplace of liquid crystal displays. Hosted by Dr. R. Selinger, students learned about liquid crystal multidisciplinary research and local graduate programs (pictured: 2017 trip).
    Kiril A Streletzky
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 3: REU trip to KSU Liquid Crystal Institute (2017)
  • 2017 REU cohort students S. Hudson (left) and J. Matz (right) together with CSU-supported student and member of 2019 cohort S. Tietjen (center) at the Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics (CUWiP) in Toledo OH (January 2018). CUWiP was one of 9 regional conferences attended by REU students.
    Samantha Tietjen
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 4: 2017 REU Students at CUWiP
  • Scientific outreach by undergraduates: In 2019 REU program hosted 90 high school kids from John Hay (Cleveland public year-round school). The REU students briefly introduced their REU research projects and their reasons for doing them and made LN2 ice cream for the John Hay students.
    Kiril A Streletzky
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 6: 2019 Outreach Session by REU students for John Hay high school kids
  • REU students attending special meeting with Dr. Janna Levin, a theoretical cosmologist, who gave a talk Creativity from Limits for CSU�s AHA! Festival in 2018. Yearly REU Science Colloquia had 3 soft matter science/engineering talks from regional scientists (NASA Glenn, Kent State, CWRU, U Akron).
    Kiril A Streletzky
    Public Domain
    Kiril Streletzky
    Picture 5: REU students attend a 2018 meeting with Dr. Janna Levin at CSU
por.por_txt_cntn:
The primary goal of the REU site at Cleveland State University (CSU) was to guide three cohorts of motivated undergraduates through the scientific method via an independent, scientifically significant research project. In doing so we (a) taught students the basics of research; (b) developed their technical communication and research dissemination skills; (c) encouraged them to consider graduate school; and (d) immersed them in a highly collaborative network of nurturing mentors committed to guiding them through their careers.

The REU included 12 projects advised or co-advised by 9 faculty in the physics and chemical/biomedical engineering departments at CSU. 26 REU students from 18 colleges in 10 states alongside 5 CSU-sponsored students advanced the projects in soft-matter physics with three research foci:

Polymers, proteins, and gels: Can an understanding of protein and polymer fundamental properties and phase transitions help us harness the power of environmentally sensitive nanoparticles and gels?
Self-Assembly and Anisotropic Soft Matter: Can we drive self-assembly of anisotropic soft matter to exploit its properties for applications ranging from electronics to biomimetics?
Soft Matter Fluid Flow: Can we better understand and improve mixing in liquid systems and use liquid flow to test and understand biological phenomena?


The REU had positive outcomes in terms of Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts.

Intellectual Merit:

The REU students have made significant contributions to scientific knowledge through 88 presentations (most by the students themselves) at 9 local, 9 regional, and 12 national conferences as well as through 9 peer-reviewed publications, 2 peer-reviewed abstracts,1 US utility patent application, and 5 manuscripts in preparation. This volume of work contributed to the body of knowledge in the three REU research foci:

            A. Polymers, proteins, and gels:

Studies of swelling/deswelling mechanism and dynamics of environmentally sensitive polymeric microgels: Freeman et al., Macromolecules 53, 11, 9244 (2020); Tietjen et al., The Ohio Journal of Science 118, A49 (2018); Scherer et al., in preparation.
Developing wet scanning electron microscopy technique to visualize the dynamics of microgels in solution: Tietjen et al., JURP, 30, 1, 31 (2021); Dobrila et al., The Ohio Journal of Science 118, A48 (2018).
A study of phase transitions in absinthe to understand the formation of the milky louche upon cold water addition: Bickel et al., ACS Omega, 6, 17674 (2021).
A study to design, express, and characterize protein-based hydrogel nanoparticles that can trap and release drugs: Maraschky et al., in preparation.


            B. Self-Assembly and Anisotropic Soft Matter:

A study of purification, structural control, and self-assembly of Boron Nitride nanotubes which may be used for thermal interface materials and optoelectronics: Kode et al., ACS App. Nano Materials 2, 2099 (2019); Ao,G., Aligned Boron Nitride Nanotube Films, US utility patent application #16/775,319 (2020).
A study of organic molecule crystallization via surface reconstructions and simulations that can be used for electronics: Martin et al. in preparation.
Microscopy/scattering studies of Janus/anisotropic particles: Rashidi et al. in preparation.


            C: Soft Matter Fluid Flow

Studies of mixing in microfluidic channels and mixers of various geometries: Clark et al. COMSOL Conference 1 (2018); Micromachines 9, 107 (2018); J. Micromechanics and Microengineering 29, 075012 (2019).
A study of gold nanoparticle formation in microfluidic mixers: Sarsfield et al., Chemical Engineering Technology 44, 622 (2021).
Studies of the mechanical structure of primary cilia, which is important for understanding the kidney disease: Praljak et al., Mathematical Biosciences & Engineering 17, 1787 (2020); Resnick et al., in preparation.


Broader Impacts:

Benefiting science and technology via published/presented results and the patent.
Advancing STEM education by helping 26 REU and 5 CSU-sponsored students develop research, technical communication, and professional development skills.      

REU engaged students in independent research - a new experience for many participants as 65% came from departments that do not offer PhD (e.g. with limited research opportunities). Student assessments showed significant growth in research-related skills after REU (e.g. 22% growth in student ability to identify next research steps and 50% in ability to present research).


Helping students to build a research network with peers, faculty mentors, and STEM researchers.      

Student participation at local/regional/national conferences (pic 1), REU Science Colloquia, and trips to NASA and Liquid Crystal Institute (pics 2&3) expanded their networks.


Inspiring ~21% of students into graduate studies (percentage of students interested climbed from 56% before to 77% after the REU). Currently, 66% of REU alumni are in graduate programs (10 PhD/7 MS); another 12% plan to do it. Two REU alumni received NSF?s Graduate Research Fellowships.
Encouraging highly collaborative and interdisciplinary research environment by the nature of REU projects, student interdepartmental co-advising, and Colloquia speaker selection.
Supporting women by admitting 20% of the cohort (national physics average); promoting CUWiP conferences and women physicist speakers (pics 4&5).
Promoting STEM within the general public and training students in the importance of public scientific communication via outreach to high school students by REU participants (pic 6).
